subject: Re: [junit] Question
msgSnippet: ... I assume you want to run many tests at one time. The normal way is to create a class that collects the TestCase classes together: public class AllTests {
messageBody:
> Hi everybody,
> I've written a TestCase for one class.
> Is there a way to test another class with this test?
> The problem is: it is impossible to pass second one as parameter to "Test
> suite()" method (as it is static and passing will give one result:
> last class will be tested twice). Changing test is not really good
> (as there will be some more classes that I would like to test with
> TestCase).

I assume you want to run many tests at one time. The normal way is to create
a class that collects the TestCase classes together:

public class AllTests {
public static Test suite() {
final TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();

suite.addTestSuite( MyFirstTestCase.class );
suite.addTestSuite( MySecondTestCase.class );

return suite;
}
}

Now run AllTests instead of the two test cases separately.

Notice these things:

1. AllTests does not extend TestCase. It is not necessary.
2. If MyFirstTestCase has special test setup and declares its own suite()
method, you must change this line to:

suite.addTest( MyFirstTestCase.suite() );

This is common when a test case uses a test-decorator extension from
junit.extensions.*.

I hope this helps.

Also: you should use test case classes to group similar tests together. There
is no rule to say "One test case class per production code class." Group the
tests together in a way that you will be able to understand later when you
read the tests.
